## 
 <span style="font-size: 22px;"><span style="margin-right: 30px;"></span> In this project, lidar data from MKRF research forest are used to generate high-resolution digital elevation models (DEM) and Canopy Height models (CHM) for terrain analysis, vegetation mapping, and various remote sensing applications. </span><br>

## Method
 <span style="font-size: 22px;"><span style="margin-right: 30px;"></span> To generate the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) and Canopy Height Model (CHM), the lidar data stored in a .las file was first loaded and inspected using <strong>readLAS()</strong> and <strong>las_check()</strong> from the lidR package in R, identifying issues such as duplicate points, which were removed with <strong>filter_duplicates()</strong>. The Digital Elevation Model (DEM) was created using  <strong>rasterize_terrain()</strong> with the tin() algorithm.</span><br>
 
  <span style="font-size: 22px;"><span style="margin-right: 30px;"></span> The DSM was then generated by rasterizing the highest lidar returns with <strong>rasterize_canopy() </strong>, capturing the uppermost surfaces. Since the CHM represents vegetation height above the ground, the lidar point cloud was normalized using <strong>normalize_height()</strong>, which adjusted elevation values so that ground points were set to zero. Finally, the Canopy Height Model (CHM) was derived from the normalized LiDAR data using <strong>rasterize_canopy()</strong>, representing vegetation heights across the study area.</span><br>
  

<span style="font-size: 22px;"><span style="margin-right: 30px;"></span>    </span><br>

## R

``` (.r)
library(lidR)
Raw_MKRF_Las <- readLAS("LAS/MKRF.las")
MKRF_Las_Filtered <- filter_duplicates(Raw_MKRF_Las)  #Removes Duplicated points

DEM_MKRF <- rasterize_terrain(MKRF_Las_Filtered, 2, tin())
DSM_MKRF <- rasterize_canopy(MKRF_Las_Filtered, res = 1, algorithm = p2r())

#CHM can be derived using DSM - DEM or using normalization method
Normalized_MHRF <- normalize_height(MKRF_Las_Filtered, DEM_MKRF)
CHM_MHRF <- rasterize_canopy(Normalized_MHRF, 2, p2r())
```
